awd_titl_txt: Implementing DNA Barcoding for Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
A universal product code is a unique pattern of vertical lines that can identify specific consumer product.  In a comparable way, a DNA barcode is a unique pattern of DNA sequence that can potentially identify specific species of living things. Understanding and using DNA barcoding requires ideas from molecular biology, genetics, evolution, systematics, ecology, and biodiversity, all of which are key concepts in traditional introductory biology courses. Building on the growing evidence that early exposure to research increases retention of students in STEM disciplines, this project will enable DNA barcoding course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) for large numbers of students. This project will provide a series of summer workshops to train 80 undergraduate faculty from around the country, so that they can teach students how to use DNA barcoding to identify a diverse population of organisms. With a relatively small investment of time, these students will have the real possibility of discovering a new barcode and publishing it on GenBank, as practicing scientists do. By participating in projects that track species through time and space, students can contribute new knowledge about how plants and animals are responding to their environment. DNA barcode research requires the "soft skills" of collaborating, persisting, and presenting ideas, which any student would need to succeed in his or her future career. The students will also develop expertise in analysis, manipulation, and integration of data from different sources, as well as visualization of data.  These skills are especially relevant for the future workforce.  

Advanced metabarcoding CUREs will be developed in microbiome and environmental DNA analysis to introduce faculty and students to next generation sequencing and data science. The goals of this project are to introduce undergraduate educators to basic DNA barcoding technology and help them develop the additional expertise needed to understand and use DNA metabarcoding. DNA metabarcoding embodies the conceptual transition of modern biology from single gene to massively parallel genome analysis. The project objectives are to: 1) Develop technology to reduce costs and barriers to classroom implementation of DNA barcoding and metabarcoding. 2) Train faculty in DNA barcoding and metabarcoding technology, data science, and effective methods for scaling CUREs to reach large numbers of students. 3) Provide mentoring and extended collaborative support to faculty as they implement CUREs and extend their expertise to data science. 4) Evaluate the program and provide unified measures of the impact of barcoding research experiences on student self-efficacy and persistence in STEM. An ambitious evaluation program will attempt to determine which of the key elements of CUREs (engaging in scientific practices, collaborating, examining relevant problems, exploring questions with unknown answers, and re-iterating experiments) most closely correlates with positive student outcomes. The project will integrate three levels of investigation: fieldwork, in vitro biochemistry, and in silico bioinformatics. The bioinformatics analysis of barcodes provides students with an increasingly sophisticated repertoire of data science skills and statistical reasoning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Course-based Undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) provide a mechanism to expose large numbers of students to biological research, which increases student interest and retention in STEM disciplines and on-time graduation.  DNA barcoding is an especially appropriate topic around which to organize CUREs, because it embodies many key concepts taught in traditional introductory biology courses, including molecules of life, genetics, taxonomy, evolution, ecology, and biodiversity. DNA barcoding also entails lab skills needed for employment in the advanced technological workforce, and it exposes students to all phases of the data life cycle, from data generation to analysis and sharing.

This project adds to the body of work validating the importance of CUREs in undergraduate education and offers guidance to CURE implementation in other disciplines. It demonstrated that faculty can be supported to move research experiences into lower-level courses, where CUREs can impact more students and more of their college careers. The project supported broad implementation of DNA barcoding CURES with: 1) improved methods, shared resources, and online infrastructure; 2) faculty training and classroom support; 3) documented student impacts, and 4) incorporation of emerging nanopore sequencing technology.

The freshman DNA barcoding sequence at James Madison University reaches about 1,700 students per year.  Detailed lesson plans and materials for this model CURE were published in CourseSource (https://tinyurl.com/JMUBIO) and have been downloaded 4,000 times since publication in 2021. DNA Barcoding 101 (https://dnabarcoding101.org), the DNALC’s website of methods and resources, was expanded with new sections on eDNA analysis and nanopore sequencing. Four chapters by project staff were published in the compendium DNA Barcoding: Methods and Protocols.  These include simple methods for DNA extraction, plant and animal barcoding, and a guide to DNA Subway, the major educational workflow for DNA barcode analysis. The DNALC received ATE funding to update DNA Subway 2.0 as a mobile-first application, which will be the first set of high-level bioinformatics tools to run smoothly on a smartphone. Updated DNA barcode analysis both Sanger and nanopore sequences will be available in Spring 2025. 

Over 300 faculty received training over the term of the project, through a workshop series conducted at the outset of the grant; follow-on activities conducted at the collaborating institutions, and a culminating workshop series in the final year.  A retrospective survey of 51 of 111 faculty involved in workshops during the initial phase of the project (2019-21) showed that the vast majority had implemented DNA barcoding by incorporating concepts and experiments into pre-existing courses and 40% had implemented a new CURE. These faculty have provided DNA barcoding experiments to 8,000 students since their training. The vast majority of faculty had received support from the project co-PIs, including free reagents and DNA sequencing, implementation planning, and help troubleshooting biochemistry or with bioinformatics analysis. DNA barcoding had been implemented in a variety courses, including introductory biology, molecular biology, biotechnology, genetics, microbiology, and ecology.  Consistent with the importance of early introduction to research, 63% of barcoding experiments occurred at the introductory level (mainly freshman). Importantly, the respondents had disseminated DNA barcoding to 750 other faculty members at their own institutions, at professional meetings, and at hands-on workshops they conducted. 

More than 4,200 students completed post-instruction surveys, affirming that their DNA barcoding experiences had embodied important characteristics of scientific research, including: understanding the theory and concepts guiding their research, formulating research questions, contributing ideas during discussions, identifying research limitations, revising their analyses and results, investigating something previously unknown, determining next steps in their project, testing new hypotheses, and generating novel results.  For the majority, their barcoding experiences made them feel capable of going further in science and increased their interest in studying science.

Although students can readily isolate and amplify DNA in the collegiate classroom, determining the nucleotide sequence of a DNA barcode is primarily done at academic or commercial sequencing centers. So, under a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Oxford Nanopore Technologies, the DNALC became the major educational partner to develop its MinION device as an affordable DNA sequencer for classroom use. Pedagogically, this removes the black box of DNA sequencing and engages students in all aspects of DNA barcoding.  In addition to adapting nanopore protocols for the teaching laboratory, the DNALC worked with Oxford Nanopore to develop education pricing for start-up equipment and reagent kits at $1,500, less than half the research cost.  The Summer of Nanopore Sequencing 2024 provided three-day training for 135 faculty at workshops conducted at seven locations across the US. A 2.5-day meeting at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Banbury Center, Fulfilling the Promise of Nanopore Sequencing in Education, drew together 28 experts and opinion leaders to consider how to operationalize the vision of a nanopore sequencer in every biology teaching lab. These efforts, in conjunction with the mobile DNA Subway 2.0 platform, will make DNA barcode analysis available to anyone, any time, any place.
